```/opt/bin/x86_64-apple-darwin14-libgfortran3-cxx03/install_name_tool -id LLVMEnzyme-9.dylib lib/LLVMEnzyme-9.dylib```

I've asked about this before, but it has gotten lost to slack history limit.
I'm still having some trouble getting a local run of the `GDAL` Yggdrasil script to work.

I am now working on `1.6.0-DEV` (compiled from the `release-1.6` branch)

`Version 1.6.0-DEV.1780 (2020-12-19)`
`release-1.6/de69b02a48 (fork: 58 commits, 19 days)`

and I am using the `master` branches of `BinaryBuilder` and `BinaryBuilderBase`

`[12aac903] BinaryBuilder v0.3.0 <https://github.com/JuliaPackaging/BinaryBuilder.jl.git#master>`
`[7f725544] BinaryBuilderBase v0.5.0 <https://github.com/JuliaPackaging/BinaryBuilderBase.jl.git#master>`

running `julia build_tarballs.jl --verbose --debug` fails resolving dependency versions like:

```[ Info: Copying content of bundled in srcdir...
   Resolving package versions...
ERROR: LoadError: Unsatisfiable requirements detected for package LibSSH2_jll [29816b5a]:
 LibSSH2_jll [29816b5a] log:
 ├─possible versions are: 1.9.1 or uninstalled
 └─restricted to versions 1.9.0 by an explicit requirement — no versions left
Stacktrace:
  [1] check_constraints(graph::Pkg.Resolve.Graph)```
I have also tried on a nightly build with the same results.

`Version 1.7.0-DEV.45 (2020-12-13)`
`Commit 8f2b0e7176 (15 days old master)`

It passes CI and builds in the <https://dev.azure.com/JuliaPackaging/Yggdrasil/_build/results?buildId=8050&view=logs&j=602baf21-6ef1-59f6-fbf0-2d9fa93f2756&t=01a2bb1e-9661-5612-34b4-6bc9235fd7d7|Azure pipeline> . Are there any other differences in the CI environment that I would need to make to get it working locally?

I am seeing this on Yggdrasil when rebuilding libjulia_jll 1.5.3 (no actual changes, just rebuilding it):
```[12:01:23]  ---> apk add coreutils libuv-dev utf8proc
[12:01:23] ERROR: unsatisfiable constraints:
[12:01:23]   ninja (virtual):
[12:01:23]     provided by: samurai
[12:01:23]     required by: world[ninja]
[12:01:23]  ---> apk add coreutils libuv-dev utf8proc
[12:01:23] Previous command exited with 1
[12:01:23] Child Process exited, exit code 1```
Huh?

Julia CI tests for buildbot/package_win32 and buildbot/package_win64 are failing with error: `
```C:/buildbot/worker/package_win32/build/usr/tools/llvm-size.exe: error while loading shared libraries: LLVM.dll: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory```

messages.text:
<@U66GD0880> <@UDB26738Q>  So... there seem to be issues in building this...
<https://julialang.slack.com/archives/C674ELDNX/p1609619097249600>

I propose a Qt6_jll
1. This will be an experiment where I just test how Qt6_jll builds with the build_tarballs.jl of Qt_jll
2. <@U6V6FEY1L> is working on a Qt6 version of QML.jl. Whenever he decides to release it, we can delete Qt6_jll and copy its build_tarballs.jl to that of Qt_jll
3. qttools 6.0.0 has cmake support, unlike 5.15.2. It should become easier to build a binary out of that. For that we require qt6 binaries.

messages.text: If someone wants a job doing this stuff contact me: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/devops-and-mlops-with-the-mit-julia-lab/52795>

attachments.title: Devops and MLops with the MIT Julia Lab
attachments.text: We’re looking for a new devops and MLops engineer to work with the Julia Lab. You’d be in charge of keeping all of our systems running and creating new schemes to accelerate Julia development. Julia’s Base CI, the FluxML, SciML and GPU resources are managed by this position. Automated benchmarking tools, automating the installation of Julia in R and Python packages, helping improve Julia’s setup for compute clusters, building tools to make it easy to manage ML training in Git repositories, etc. ...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: Devops and MLops with the MIT Julia Lab

I want to help kick the ball forward on switching over to LLVM’s libunwind.
i.e. <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/30154>

For packaging it, should it be its own `LibUnwind_LLVM_jll` or bundled into the LLVM jlls?

elements.text:
I want to help kick the ball forward on switching over to LLVM’s libunwind.
i.e.
For packaging it, should it be its own
or bundled into the LLVM jlls?

messages.text: Does it just need to dynamically link to LLVM without requiring the full source tree? IIRC when I tried it years ago, it had to be pretty ingrained into the LLVM build, which would suggest to me that it'd be easier to incorporate it into LLVM_jll. If that's not the case (or no longer the case at least) then perhaps a separate jll is easier for now?

messages.text: Why the `32` in the Windows 64-bit platform? I just got tricked by it `Windows (x86_64-w64-mingw32)`

elements.text: in the Windows 64-bit platform? I just got tricked by it

messages.text: that's the name of the target: <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mingw-w64>.  the reason is probably historic?

attachments.title: Mingw-w64
attachments.text:
Mingw-w64 is a free and open source software development environment to create Microsoft Windows PE applications. It was forked in 2005–2008 from MinGW (Minimalist GNU for Windows).
Mingw-w64 includes a port of the GNU Compiler Collection (GCC), GNU Binutils for Windows (assembler, linker, archive manager), a set of freely distributable Windows specific header files and static import libraries which enable the use of the Windows API, a Windows native build of the GNU Project's GNU Debugger, and miscellaneous utilities.
Mingw-w64 can be run either on the native Microsoft Windows platform, cross-hosted on Linux (or other Unix), or "cross-native" on MSYS2 or Cygwin. Mingw-w64 can generate 32 bit and 64-bit executables for x86 under the target names i686-w64-mingw32 and x86_64-w64-mingw32.

elements.text: that's the name of the target:

messages.text:
> Mingw-w64 can generate 32 bit and 64-bit executables for x86 under the target names i686-w64-mingw32 and x86_64-w64-mingw32.
Yeah. That’s unfortunate

elements.text: Mingw-w64 can generate 32 bit and 64-bit executables for x86 under the target names i686-w64-mingw32 and x86_64-w64-mingw32.

I'm starting to work on a  <https://github.com/JuliaPackaging/Yggdrasil/pull/2349|PDAL build>.
I have a situation where multiple platforms are failing on the same line, but all giving different errors on each platform. They all sound like some kind of bash error making me suspect some kind of CMake expansion weirdness? Stuff like:

`line 1: syntax error: unexpected ")"`

`line 1: syntax error: unterminated quoted string`

Has anyone run into anything like this before?
This project has the most expansive CMake set up I have worked with (uses policies and custom_targets) and I may just be getting out of my depth

messages.text: The command it is failing on is (expanded) `cd /workspace/srcdir/PDAL-2.2.0-src/build && /workspace/srcdir/PDAL-2.2.0-src/build/bin/dimbuilder /workspace/srcdir/PDAL-2.2.0-src/pdal/Dimension.json /workspace/srcdir/PDAL-2.2.0-src/build/include/pdal/Dimension.hpp` where `dimbuilder` is a compiled utility that gets built as part of the process. <https://github.com/PDAL/PDAL/blob/master/cmake/dimension.cmake|here> is the relevant sub-cmake script being called. I have already had to patch this once to make sure the exectuable is being found correctly

So, current Julia master as well as Julia 1.6 branch cannot be used to build a bunch of Yggdrasil packages (anything which requires older versions of stuff which is now bundled as "fake"  JLL stdlibs, such as GMP_jll or OpenBLAS_jll. That means that in order to test build those packages locally, one has to (a) know about this and (b) use a Julis build from a commit predating the fake JLL merged. My question: is there a plan already how to tackle this? Also, should there perhaps be an issue for this (to track progress, but also to point people to it who run into the problem)

elements.text: So, current Julia master as well as Julia 1.6 branch cannot be used to build a bunch of Yggdrasil packages (anything which requires older versions of stuff which is now bundled as "fake"  JLL stdlibs, such as GMP_jll or OpenBLAS_jll. That means that in order to test build those packages locally, one has to (a) know about this and (b) use a Julis build from a commit predating the fake JLL merged. My question: is there a plan already how to tackle this? Also, should there perhaps be an issue for this (to track progress, but also to point people to it who run into the problem)

messages.text: (I can file such an issue if that's deemed helpful)

elements.text: (I can file such an issue if that's deemed helpful)

messages.text: The first step in the plan is to teach BB to look in these fake JLLs for a `StdlibArtifacts.toml` file and download that artifact instead of the normal ones.  The next step is to further firm up the `julia_version` antics and make sure that you can actually install against a `MbedTLS_jll` that installs on Julia v1.5, if you want to.

elements.text: The first step in the plan is to teach BB to look in these fake JLLs for a
file and download that artifact instead of the normal ones.  The next step is to further firm up the
antics and make sure that you can actually install against a
that installs on Julia v1.5, if you want to.

messages.text: an alternative is to directly use Pkg's resolver instead of relying on it through `Pkg.add`

elements.text: an alternative is to directly use Pkg's resolver instead of relying on it through

messages.text: Yeah, it may be that the `StdlibArtifacts.toml` stuff is a little too painful when combined with `Pkg.add()`.  We’ll see.  I plan on working on this soon; I’ve chewed through enough of my other work that it’s close to the top of my priority list. :slightly_smiling_face:

Question about custom repos for artifacts: I use `--deploy=jstrube/repo_jll.jl` to copy artifacts to my own github instead of JuliaBinaryWrappers. How do I tell Pkg to get them from there? The docs talk about an Override.toml, but the example looks like it's for the case where a binarybuilder project depends on another artifact. Does Override.toml also work for the case where a normal Julia package depends on the artifact? In that case I just pass the http link for the repo? I'm not sure I grok the example...

elements.text: Question about custom repos for artifacts: I use

to copy artifacts to my own github instead of JuliaBinaryWrappers. How do I tell Pkg to get them from there? The docs talk about an Override.toml, but the example looks like it's for the case where a binarybuilder project depends on another artifact. Does Override.toml also work for the case where a normal Julia package depends on the artifact? In that case I just pass the http link for the repo? I'm not sure I grok the example...
